questions.question_text: After upgrading a laptop's OS from Windows Vista to Windows 10, hard drive activity is elevated when running normal user applications, causing the laptop to run slowly. Which of the following should a technician do FIRST?

discussion.content:
Answer should be B. Increased memory requirements for the new OS is resulting in applications not having access to enough memory. 

The windows machine is having to rely on the page file constantly. The page file uses disk storage and this is resulting in the constant activity of the disk and of course slow down because hard drive speed is much slower than RAM. While the question does not mention Ram. CompTIA wants you to recognize concepts like memory requirements for software and OS, the speed of a hard drive vs the speed of Ram among other concepts.

comments.content: Agree with you with pearson cram exam and professor messer cram exam they talk about these.

discussion.content:
Best thing to do (key word) FIRST. CompTIA training says to do the simplest and less intrusive thing first. 
Answer is: A.
answer would be B: if we're asked what will SOLVE this problem.

1GB of RAM is just enough for basic operations like web browsing (although don't expect to run a browser with dozens of tabs open), email, word processing, and light image editing. And even these basic tasks are going to be painful. Do yourself a favor and avoid 1GB of RAM if you can..

It is B. Why would you move all of some ones files on to a USB what if they have 2TS's worth of data. good luck sliding that on onto your USB in a timely manner.
Nope. This is a pretty dim witted thing to do BEFORE backing up the data. Even if you are not replacing the hard disk, it is still necessary to do a backup when making these big changes to the system

I think the answer is C. Sounds like a hard drive problem so I suppose backing up the data before you do any changes make sense. 

I don't believe the answer is B because 2GB of ram meet the minimum requirement for 64-bit windows 10. That should still let you get some real work done. 

Also, the first solution should most definitely not be flashing your bios. Bios update isn't going to improve performance, it is typically there to do bug fixes with obscure pieces of hardware or add support for a new model of CPU. Not to mention flashing a bio is a dangerous procedure so you better know what you are doing. 

Even if we suppose updating the bios made sense, then you still have to update your data because there are cases where the bios don't work with your hard drive and it can blow your data away.

comments.content:
I think A is right guys Check this out

https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/all/a-system-bios-update-is-required-before-upgrading/c181fb9b-a7a0-42ac-9df2-0893c3832e3f

Which of the following should a technician do FIRST?

Yes. They wouldve said "which would most likely solve the issue?"
After going through it again I think your right. Comptia want you to always do the least intrusive thing first and I think C is the best answer!

choices.B: Replace both of the installed 1GB SoDIMMs with compatible 4GB SoDIMMs.
choices.A: Flash the laptop BIOS to the most current version available from the manufacturer.
choices.C: Attach an external USB hard drive and move all user data off the internal drive.
choices.D: Upgrade the currently installed 500GB SSD with a 1TB SSD.

questions.question_text: A technician finishes building a custom gaming computer. When the system is turned on, however, all the fans spin and the LEDs light up on the motherboard, but the system does not POST and the monitor remains blank. Which of the following did the technician fail to connect to the motherboard?

discussion.content: The Motherboard would POST without the HDD signal cable connected. It would not post without the CPU power cable connected.

comments.content: So why is the suggested answer A then?

discussion.content: Wow, this site's Suggested Answers are intentionally wrong at times. Answer is: B

comments.content: Even by exclusion. Can’t be D because motherboard is on. Can’t be C Power Led is on. Can’t be B the system is on. Only option left is A.

discussion.content: B. it would POST then display a no boot device error

no POST means CPU and/or Motherboard do not function.
But some Fans get their power through the Motherboard, so the CPU is the Problem

The reason I believe its (A) is because there is a good chance that the Operating system is on the HDD. I had to rebuild a PC that wouldn't post because the HDD in the PC completely failed.

If it was a CPU issue there would be POST beeps. Let me know what you think.

Selected Answer: B
So B...
Agreed

questions.question_text: A user wants to build a new home computer that will be used exclusively for the latest offline games. The user consults with a technician on the best hardware to purchase. The user has already picked out the CPU, GPU, RAM, and motherboard, but is unsure what else is important to achieve top performance. Which of the following should the technician suggest? (Choose two.)

comments.content: Yes. This is the correct answer

discussion.content: Liquid cooling, not pcie. The user already picked out the Mobo they wanted

Selected Answer: DF
PCIe? Really? I don't trust these answers at all anymore without triple checking.
PCIe slots can add on separately?!

Selected Answer: BD
Liquid cooling provides the ability to overclock the system. CPUs come with thermal paste already applied to them. As the user only 'picked out' not 'bought' the components, we should point out the PCIe to be used with GPU to get the highest performance. This is most reasonable explanation IMHO. I choose B and D.
why not pcie(for better visuals and performance) and liquid cooling

First, ipconfig /release is executed to force the client to immediately give up its lease by sending the server a DHCP release notification which updates the server's status information and marks the old client's IP address as "available". Then, the command ipconfig /renew is executed to request a new IP address

questions.question_text:
A technician recently installed a new router. Since the installation was completed, a user's PC loses network connectivity when another user's PC comes online.
Which of the following commands are BEST for the technician to run to resolve this issue? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Write caching has been turned on.

questions.question_text: An administrator notices the RAID 5 array is reporting a degraded health message. It contains three HDDs. A technician replaces the faulty HDD with a new one, but users then report access to the fileshare is not as fast as it used to be. Which of the following is MOST likely preventing the RAID array from operating optimally?

discussion.content: Would the answer not be D: The array is rebuilding. It's RAID 5 so performance will be slower while it's rebuilding the lost disk

comments.content: Not to mention the set up is RAID 5, meaning you can only lose one drive. Replacing the wrong drive would leave the array broken. 1 bad drive, 1 blank drive and only 1 drive with any data on it. Users still have access to their data which means the correct drive was replaced.
Agree. the answer is D. the question has already mentioned that the technician replaces the (((faulty))) HDD with a new one.

discussion.content: "technician replaces the faulty HDD with a new one". there is no chance for C to be correct answer. 1000GB will take 1 day and 3hours to rebuid a RAID 5 drive.
I have this problem recently in my work, and rebuild the RAID array was the solution after replace the degraded disk. So, is the D.

Selected Answer: D
The new Harddisc has to be rebuilded: Every Byte has to be calculated through Parity, that need time. But after the Rebuilding (which needs perhaps hours) the RAID 5 should be fast as before.

Selected Answer: D
D. The RAID array is rebuilding.
